docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the giant health insurer, is expected to announce today that it is buying the health care business of the New York Life Insurance Company for $1.05 billion in cash. Reflecting some of the negotiating that has gone into the deal and some of the uncertainties in the health care business, Aetna has agreed to pay New York Life as much as $300 million more if the unit, NYLCare Health Plans, meets certain growth targets in the next two years, people close to the transaction said.

headline.main: Aetna Deal for New York Life's Health Unit Is Expected Today

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc is reportedly buying NYLCare Health Plans, health care business of New York Life Insurance Co, for $1.05 billion in cash; reportedly will pay as much as $300 million more if NYLCare meets certain growth targets in next two years; NYLCare provides health insurance for 2.2 million people, including 1.5 million under managed care; Aetna has 13.7 million health insurance customers; merger is not expected to have immediate effect on costs, benefits or physician relationships for customers of two companies; analysts say melding NYLCare with Aetna may prove challenging, in light of difficulties Aetna has had in absorbing US Healthcare, which it acquired in 1996 (M)
docs.snippet: Aetna Inc., the giant health insurer, is expected to announce today that it is buying the health care business of the New York Life Insurance Company for $1.05 billion in cash.    Reflecting some of the negotiating that has gone into the deal and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Eldora Mitchell is nearly as old as the century, and for her it has been a life of love and service, starting at the age of 12, when she went to work scrubbing white people's floors to help her family. Later, she cleaned hospital rooms to feed her own children and cared for her grandchildren while their parents were working. In her 60's, she nursed her dying husband and her elderly mother. Now, at 95, frail and slowly going blind, it is Mrs. Mitchell's turn. Four years ago, she moved across town to her retirement home -- a bedroom in her son Charles's house here, with bright green curtains and her large-print Bible on the nightstand.

headline.main: Blacks Carry Load of Care for Their Elderly

docs.abstract: Black Americans continue tradition of caring for their aging mothers and fathers and grandparents; tradition is not unique to blacks, but blacks are twice as likely as whites to receive care from family members when their health declines; Jacqueline Jones, historian, traces tradition to blacks' historic lack of access to good medical care, public support and kinds of jobs that guaranteed secure old age; in population as a whole, studies show nearly one in four American families is taking care of elderly relative or friend; this is expected to increase as ranks of 'the old old' grow ever larger; experts worry that in black community, economic stress and increased mobility will prevent coming generations from taking on caregiving role; experts say there is more of resistance to institutional care among blacks than whites; stories abound among African-Americans about relatives and friends being mistreated in nursing homes; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kirsten M. Schiefler, a daughter of Dr. Donald Schiefler of Calgary, Alberta, and the late Doreen Schiefler, was married on Feb. 17 to Dr. Norman A. Ernst Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst of Dunedin, Fla. The Rev. Frank Mak of the Joyful Christian Ministries officiated at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Waikiki.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR those who wonder what life might be like if American lawyers had their wings clipped, a visit to almost any German playground or swimming pool is instructive. At the Opel Zoo, a petting zoo and playground in this suburb outside Frankfurt, one of the most popular attractions is an army-style cable ride. Children climb up a six-foot-high platform, grab a bar that hangs from an overhead pulley, and then whizz down a 40-foot cable as if they were Green Berets vaulting a treacherous gorge. The ride comes to a jolting and thrilling stop when the pulley smacks into a rubber tire about 10 feet off the ground. The bar and child swing wildly in all directions before gradually coming to a rest.

headline.main: The World: When Bad Things Happen to German People; Where a Lawsuit Can't Get Any Respect

docs.abstract: European acceptance of accidents as fact of life in places like playgrounds and swimming pools contrasts with peculiarly American notion of 'riskless society,' and litigation that inevitably follows; photo; Germans have little hope of winning suits in case of accidents, although they are in other ways at least as litigious as Americans, and routinely carry lawyers' insurance to pay their legal fees; Germans generally sue each other, and stakes are much smaller than in US, where plaintiffs sue government, corporations and doctors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOWHERE in the country has breast cancer activism been so influential as on Long Island in enlisting volunteers, gaining political support and obtaining government and private funds, even leading to the issuing of a breast-cancer postage stamp. Grassroots efforts concentrated on the hundred-mile stretch spanning two counties have spawned a $21.4 million Federal study of possible environmental links to the disease and a demographic mapping survey that has since been requested by other states and countries.
docs.abstract: Breast cancer movement on Long Island evolves from simple hands-on volunteer operation in 1990 into sophisticated charitable enterprises that are increasingly being run like businesses; there are 16 activist coalitions on Island, which has higher rate of breast cancer than most other regions in New York State and US; photos (L)
